We visited during a brief break in Nantes. Entry into the castle was free allowing us to walk along the ramparts and gardens. Good views of Nantes and pleasant enough with plenty of people relaxing on the lawns in the most area. The museum was OK, a bit hit and miss with some
A good warm sunny day would be perfect when visiting this chateau. It is not big bit but it is relaxing enough if you just want sit or wander around.

This is a wonderful place to visit and nice of all the grounds, courtyard and ramparts are free to experience. Full of history, excellent explanatory signage in French but with English too. Gift shop and cafe available too. We did not visit the exposition which does have an
How great to be able to wander around most of this castle without charge. we did not feel the need to go inside, there was plenty to explore on the impressive ramparts.
Fascinating place packed with amazing stories of its history...again well worth a visit if you are in the area or just passing through...
We enjoyed a good hour walking the walls and enjoying the views of Nantes from this lovely castle. A short walk from the cathedral and well worth seeking out.
We walked around the castle and ramparts, pleasant views and interesting information available. There is a paid visit which we didn't bother with.

We were mightily impressed by the château in Nantes! It was the first place we went to on our arrival to Nantes, since we’d seen so many photos prior to our trip. But photos just can’t do this place justice! It’s impressive! It’s beautiful! It’s amazing! And what a beautiful

Visited the chateau in the pouring rain on route to an Indian restaurant. I didn't pay to go inside the actual buildings of the chateau where there was a history of French Pop Music Exhibition. But I did walk inside the courtyard and looked at the very impressive buildings and

This is a very interesting "castle", although it is more of a fortified palace, with the usual chequered history. Good views from the battlements and the buildings around the courtyard are beautiful. The museum is quite interesting also.

Built right in the centre of Nantes this castle served as a military base for many years. It's free to wander around the old walls and around the moat which still has water in it. There is a museum covering the slave trade any early Nantes history but not much in English.
We were lucky to visit the Castle in the first Sunday of the month, when it is free. Not too many people, but enough for all the shade tables to be occupied.

Entrance into the castle is free.Within the castle walls stand several buildings. The castle walls are impressive & you are able to walk all the way around. One of the buildings houses a very good gift shop as well as the museum. There is a charge to go into the Museum. There
Really nice fortress but missing comparible museum. A little history of slave trade but not much else.

There is a museum, gift shop, cafe, tours, but even if you don't have much time, at least walk around the grounds and go into the courtyard to appreciate the way the dukes and duchesses would have lived. The castle is well maintained and looks a little different from every
Walked round the grounds which gave some interesting information. Have seen in plenty of castles and chateau in my time so never ventured inside.

With this Chateau, the access to the grounds is free, and we didn't pay to visit the exhibitions. You can walk right around the ramparts and also the gardens below, there are some lovely views of the city and several information boards to point out landmarks etc. Only downside
Museum is very well done with a lot of interesting history of Nantes and the Chateau. Allow at least two hours. There are many interactive displays for the children.

One has the possibility to walk around the walls of the castle and visit the historical museum, which offers an excellent overview of the history of Nantes including around the figure of Anne of Brittany and how Nantes succeeded economically in the last centuries.

Had a lovely couple of hours here. It great that you can walk the wall, gardens and courtyards without paying. We paid to go into the museum but very little in English so we could of paid for the guide. Food in the restaurant was fantastic.

You can go into the courtyard and walk along the outer walls without paying. But then you would miss the excellent museum. The audio guide for the museum was excellent, and the exhibits were well presented. Definitely worth the entry fee.
Wonderful castle to visit. You can walk all the way round the walls for free which is great, but easily missed.
Worth the visit and to wander around the outside. Floodlit at night and in front the dancing fountains with many colours displayed in the water.
This is one of the most gorgeous castles. The white stone and the beautiful details uplift me every time. I enjoy the museum, too.

I spent an hour walking around on a brief visit to Nantes. It is beautifully kept and provides good insight into the area's history. It is impossible to miss this attraction due to its central location. Recommended
Wandering around feels great! you get a free tour for the garden and the surroundings of the castle. the place is old, well preserved and nice to spend a nice time there

Everytime I visit my sister who lives in Nantes, I go to the chateau.. because I love it. Not only it is beautiful, but there is always something going on. Last time I went there was live music , and a master graffiti competition on makeshift walls. How cool is that! And the

We visited on the 1st Sunday of the month, which allows free entry. Even if we’d paid the full amount it would have been worth it; the Chateau houses an excellent museum dealing with the history of Nantes across the Centuries. Excellent exhibits, including an animation sequence

Went there in the month of July and loved it. I did the tour by myself. I was just disappointed I could not use the slide going down the side of the castle, (they were doing some maintenance), but it looked very cool. The castle stands just in the middle of the old Nantes
nothing special, but nice. old, nearby center, i dont know what said more... maybe - in the night without lights-why?
Open to walk around or into the courtyard . Very impressive right in the city near the rail station so easy to find.
One of the picturesque castles I have seen, it was nice to walk on its ancient walls and see the panorama of Nantes.
This is a great place to spend some time! The castle is gorgeous. There was very decent food available inside. There were lots of interesting little shops surrounding it, so lots for everyone!
Beautiful old castle. Nice gardens around. It is the nantes history museum. The museum is very nice, it was things about the castle construction and also recent history

So cool to have a medieval castle in the middle of town. It's really well maintained and a beautiful structure. It's free to walk around and inside but there is a charge for the museum which we didn't do. It's a must when in Nantes!
Magnificent 15th century Chateau - from the ramparts, good views over Nantes … find out about the redoubtable Anne of Brittany from 5 centuries ago - pleasant cafe in the grounds.
Very impozant building. Heart od old town. Special architecture and expositions. Around Chateau is nice park. I recommend.

It was okay - Audio tour guide is a must and there is a lot to see - cafe/coffee seems to only work on hot sunny dry days - we visit on a dull drizzly day . Probably one of those places you see as a must visit but afterwards come away saying that was just okay . . . . .

As my command of French is weak, I did not expect to learn and enjoy the museum as much as I did. We even went back a second day to see the rest of the exhibits. Buy the 20 euro pass that admits you to multiple museums in Nantes over a period of a year Quite a bargain.
Stunning castle, interesting museum finished to a very high quality. Audio guides available in several languages. FYI - lots of stairs.

This place is stunning! It cost €8 each and it was well worth it with 32 rooms to look in. Information in each room is in French, English and Spanish which was fantastic for us. The outside is absolutely beautiful and the tour continues there. It is wheelchair friendly and

Definitely a must to visit when in Nantes. Impressive building which houses a museum full of interesting displays and information about the history of Nantes. Free entry and audio device in multiple languages with Nantes Tourisme City Pass .

Very beautiful castle with its moat transformed into park, in the heart of Nantes. we go there for architecture, for the ballad on the "path of the round", the history of Nantes but not for the inner rooms that offer little interest

Lovely place to take a stroll. We didn't go inside but enjoyed a free walk around the ramparts. Very informative stops at viewing points around the walk. The main toilets were closed but the little cafe was happy for us to use their faculties.

We spent hours on a visit to the museum and exhibition which was all fascinating. Plenty here to see and excellent portrayal of Nantes history. Staff were very helpful and the English translation guide was very good.

Hubby had wanted to see this chateau while we were in Nantes. After white knuckling the drive in, we were able to park in the parking lot across a grassy knoll from the chateau. It was lovely! There are books throughout the many rooms to tour in the castle, with an English
If you are in Nantes, this is an attraction not to be missed, take your time walk in and around which you can do for free.

The castle is at walking distance from downtown Nantes. It is interesting for its history, tightly connected to French Kingdom one, for the Anne de Bretagne (who married two French Kings at the Renaissance) remembering, for the furniture and the objects presented in the museum,
There is no charge to walk around the moat and the ramparts. There was also an interesting temporary exhibition of photographs. It seems to be a very well preserved and presented historical building.

In all fairness we were short on time and never went into the chateau itself. It is free to enter the courtyard and to walk the walls. We did do that and got a spectacular view of Nantes and a good feel for the magnificence of the chateau. Worth seeing.

We stopped by here, just to take some photos and have a general look around. You can pay and go inside the museum/exhibits, but we just wanted a wander around the grounds and ramparts, which is free. It's well kept and has been sympathetically restored. It has a moat going

This is a beautifully restored castle, and absolutely enormous. There are 32 rooms to explore, and a lot of stairs, although they have thoughtfully put lifts in all over the place. They have certainly gone to great trouble to make this a very good experience and if you go into

Great place. Been to a number of castles throughout Europe this is right up there, and the displays, signage and technology to assist your visit, as good as I have seen You could walk the Castle including walls at no charge, inside a reasonable fee to inspect and extremely well

Unfortunately the museum was closed when we went, However, there is a well signposted tour all around the ramparts and across the courtyard. Absolutely stunning views of the (partly rebuilt) architecture, the walls and Nantes around it. 2 hours just flew by
Chateau grounds and ramparts free to use - did not pay to look around the chateau. Slide from ramparts to ground not open on day we visited - this looks good fun

A very well preserved castle which has a free section to walk around as well as a paid area. It has a restaurant inside too. Worth a visit if visiting the area.

it's well preserved ground castles with almost all the walls and building in well preserved conditions like it's been still populated by it's peoples! english meaning of the name is " Castle of the Dukes of Brittany" and has rich history associated with it. the fortification

My two princesses (three and six) loved visiting this castle. It is free to walk around the outside. You can slide down from the top to the bottom but you must be adequately clothed to avoid any friction burns so shorts won't do. Really nice to walk around in the sunshine.
Use a guided tour as a first attempt to the visit and then do the museum again. A very well managed museum which allows people to fully undestand the history of Nantes.
Wandered around here in the early evening (it closes at 8.00pm) - was amazed at how much of the castle was open to the public free of charge - the walk around the ramparts was much fun!
Really interesting visit. The only thing-all videos are in French. May be they can think about English subtitles for the future?

Very beautiful city to visit soon going to live there. I love the city and have too much to visit the castle is incredible reminds me Portugal the castle and old this to visit very similar. Coming back soon!

My wife and I went expecting to see a chateau with hanging tapestries, furniture, etc, the sort of thing we've seen many times before but in essence the chateau is simply a museum with a history of Nantes mainly in pictures and text. It does what it does quite well but it isn't

Don’t leave Nantes without seeing this magnificent castle. Built from 13th to 16th century, this former home of Francis II and Duchess Anne has a massive story to tell. They also showcase other notable historic figures of Nantes such as the Lefèvre-Utile or better known
Stunning moated castle, spent a lovely afternoon exploring all around. Very well preserved and free to walk around

Walk the walls for free and get some interesting sights of Nantes. The walls are relatively high but nice to walk around to get a different aspect of Nantes. Good views and not difficult. Descent can be via a slide off the walls to the ground!! well good.

That's a castle which really deserves a bit of your time during the visit in Nantes. Try to take half a day to have a walk around and a visit inside. I have been told that concerts and other events are taking place here from time to time, but I haven't got the chance to join any

Great chateau with great history. Walk the ramparts for a visual guide as to how Nantes has transformed itself with diverting and redirecting the river - pity since Nantes was probably nicer with more water and less road

The castle itself is very picturesque and pretty. It has additions from different eras featuring different styles of architecture. The ramparts and exterior are free to enter. If it's a nice day and this is the part you're most interested in its a great free activity. Was busy
Spent a brilliant afternoon at the Chateau with my 11 yo daughter in which we were given a guided tour and a workshop where she made a pop-up card of the chateau. Highly recommend this attraction.

This chateau is an imposing presence in the downtown area. We paid 8E for entry and another 2E for the audioguide. Interesting content especially France's part in the slave trade for about 350 years. I think we spent 4 hours in the museum but at the end got lost from the stream

The castle is free to enter and handily has it's own tram stop. When you enter then you can walk around the courtyard and go along the ramparts. For those wanting a bit more history then there is a museum in one of the buildings covering the history of the castle and Nantes.

We subscribed the kids to an activity, which they really like. Please note we booked more than a month in advance - looks like it is quite popular. During that time (as parents were not allowed), we walked in the remparts and down to the cathedral near by. We have not been

This picture perfect castle and the walk around the courtyard and battlements is not to be missed and makes for a most fascinating visit.. If you have time please discover the gardens and moat which surround the castle and watch both the fish and the turtles swimming there. The

We spent the good part of the afternoon here, looking through all the different rooms off the museum, which cover the entire history of Nantes. The city put a lot of effort into the museum and it is well worth the money.

We had a tremendous visit to this terrific with lots to do - the museum inside is full of some very interesting rooms though you should plan to allow for at least a couple of hours to take it all in. A definite must if staying in or near Nantes.

The castle itself is impressive, that goes without saying. But we also enjoyed visiting the museum which not just illustrated the history of the castle but also about the city of Nantes. Particulary interesting was the section on the slave trade and the involvement of the
Visited the Chateau, with my teenage son and parents. Fantastic day out. Largely free of charge, this castle boasts plenty to see and do in the heart of Nantes
Beautiful chateau with a great view over Nantes. You can spend a lot of time here in the museum and walking around the place.
Worth visiting when in Nantes. There are always extra exhibitions that change during the year. Good information available and friendly staff assisting. Highly recommended

If you want to feel that you are in an old time season, visit this castle. It's not faraway from the city center. Beside it there are a large square and a park where you can have a relax if the weather is good

This is an excellent chateau & museum. There are exhibits on the history of the city, from its founding through to today. It was recently reconstructed, finished in the early 2000's. Its been exquisitely redone.

There are many other chateaus in France that are more beautiful, but if you're in Nantes, then this is a must see. It gave us a much better idea of the history of the city and region. Good for 1.5 - 2 hours.
Very average as castles go, but worth a visit to the photos and walk along the ramparts. You are probably better off to stick with the outside area and not bother with the interior.

It was build by a Bretagne Duc and his daughter Annearoumd 16 century...strong walls...strong contruction surrended by a canal and fortifications...it is situated jn the center of the city...near is the fabric of the famous Petit Beurre biscuits.

Definitely worth a visit to stroll into the courtyard and into the gardens and along the ramparts. All of this is free Inside didn't offer anything very much. It's marginal whether it's worth the price and certainly not a priority to visit in the city.

The chateau with it's precinct and fortifications is an interesting building to visit and the external parts are free to wander around. The inside of the main chateau has been converted into a very good museum about the history of Nantes and Brittany but there was no remnant of
This castle is really something special. The museum inside was very interesting and I learned a lot about Nantes. It's on a good location and the views are amazing.

The whole ambience of this Chateau is quite different to others I have seen. Great drawbridge entrance. The long stone stairs leading up from the courtyard to the battlements which gave an interesting view of a water park - go down there for an hours enjoyment playing with mist
This great chateau belong to dukes of Brittany. It was rebuild a few times. Many parts of this chateau features are of great interest.
Very interesting . The things are assembled in a very smart way . It is even interactive in some spots . You can easily spend 1:30 h there without even noticing . Awesome
Beautiful setting and beautiful architecture - a very special place to see. The square inside is well worth a look as is the view from the ramparts. But it's a great photo from outside !

This is a beautiful chateau, castle, with historic significance in the center of Nantes, France. The edict of Nantes may have been signed here, which legalized Protestantism in France or until Louie xIV revoked it causing more than 200,00 hugonauts to flee France.
Get 2h before closing (18:30) or you won't be able to visit the inside of the castle, The outside it's open until 19:30

Visited free as part of the Nantes Pass, and used the self-guided English audio tour. Absolutely brilliant and enjoyed the experience so much that the security had to come and find us to close! The audio guides are available in several languages but there were a couple of films

passed by Nantes after few years without visiting it and I finally could visit the castle which was closed for years. The Chateau offers a nice promenade and also a date with history as it has signs with different tips of history. It is definitely a must see in Nantes, I loved
well worth a visit. DIsplays are very good, Staff are so helpful. So much to do and see took a few hours to walk completely round

We walked the ramparts & listened to the audio about the castle learning about life in Nantes in the 15th C. then we went into the museum. It was absolutely outstanding sharing history through artifacts, paintings, sculptures, much of which had English translations - finally!

We were staying overnight in Nantes on our way to Cherbourg so decided to visit the Chateau after breakfast in town - lovely castle with many interesting features including the walk around the battlements. Nice views and great central location in the old part of the city.

This was more than just another chateau- it was a well laid out history of Nante and indirectly a history of France as well. We could have spent far more time here - many many interesting displays and exhibits- We did the self directed tour but in retrospect I think a guided

Well worth the visit - inside and out including below the Ramparts. Free on the first Sunday of the month. The main museum tour is well worth doing however the last sections - 23 to 26 were by far the most interesting to me featuring the Lu factory and WWI and WWII exhibitions.

Excellent restoration. Easy, free access. You can walk around the walls, fairly steep steps to the top and get good views over Nantes. In summer various attractions on site. Restaurant on site but plenty of choice just outside the chateau.Well worth a visit.
It is a really interesting museum about the history of Nantes! It is a must-see attraction for sure! Besides its historical content, it´s also a beautiful castle!
Well preserved castle palace from the duke of bretagne A must see in nantes, you may stroll the courtyard but also worth visiting the inside
Take any times for to visit the castle i think 2 hours, because this story is very interesting, it s the story of nantes, the port, the slaves.....

Fantastic chateau/fort/castle: the grounds are always open for wandering or picnicking on the grass, feeding fish and ducks in the moat or just reading on a bench. My son and I bought tickets (50% discount for him as under 25 and for me as a teacher!) and spent a few hours
We visited it because we had purchased a Nantes pass. It was a brilliant experience and would recommend with the audio guide.
Great Chateau, still is totally encircled by a moat. This place really makes you think about days gone by.

This imposing building dominates the area in Nantes between Bouffay and Duchess Anne Chateau tram stations and whose entrance is directly opposite the Office de Tourisme. The castle grounds and ramparts have free access to the public, from which panoramic views of the city can

Firstly, you can walk around the ramparts, and the courtyard on the Chateau completely free of charge! The museum thought is also well worth a visit. I tells of the History of Nantes from Roman times until the present day, with a very informative audio guide.
Beautiful castle in the middle of the city, very easy to get to, just follow the painted line on the ground.
Moat surrounded castle in heart of the city. Great views from up high. Really large courtyard. Shop & plenty of toilets. Lots to see in the castle. It's one of the must see attractions

This castle is one of the most impressive I have visited and the museum inside is wonderful and gives a very full history of Nantes from before the castle was built to present day and what has shaped the city very worth while if got the time.
As a lover of history I spent the day here and then I chose to sit in the grounds with my lunch. A wonderful experience.
Full of history, peaceful place. Beautiful architecture. In the center of a very nice city center. If you like history and architecture and calm it is for you !
I was for a business event, in the summer. The place is quite charming, and it provides awesome views of the city. It is certainly worth visiting for about 1.5 hours.
The castle of Anne de Bretagne! She was then queen of Britanny, reunited to France by mariage end of the 15th century. Interesting for history lovers and a good museum
It is a very interesting museum. I found it very clean and well organised. It has small videos about the history and well adapted for kids. I recommend it.

This is truly a most interesting castle - worth visiting; not to be missed when in Nantes. It has a large, comprehensive history museum. Its most interesting part seemed to be the one related to the history of Bretagne - as linked to Duchess Eleonore - but it's not the only one.
Free visits every first Sunday of each month. Make sure to read up before you go in. Beautiful and full of story but you might need some background. (but you need it for everywhere)

The castle entry is free, but to access few areas you need to buy tickets(8 euro per person).Entry closes after 6.The castle is pretty big and beautiful.The Nantes city skyline is visible from top.Lot of stairs, so may not be very easy for old people.
This is a nice place to go for a walk. It has nice views of the city and the displays were informative. If you go in on the first of the month, entrance to the gallery is free!

We visiting on a Saturday in November, not busy at all and easy to wander around the ramparts. Very nicely presented with lots to see. There is a charge to go inside and see the exhibitions but to walk around is free.
It's such a pleasure to walk the perimeter of this chateau and to see the historical exhibits inside and, recently, the modern sculptural installations inside the mote.

A Loire chateaux in the middle of a town! Incredible and stunning, beautiful architecture so much fun to go around ramparts and walking around - and is free!!! And fabulous little creperie just in courtyard, perfect to have a coffee or a bit while exploring.
Wonderful restored castle. Excellent museum on the history of Nantes, including the slavetrade, visits with headphones and in choice of languages. They often have art exhibitions as well.
Through the museum you get to understand the history of the chateau and of the city itself, very interesting.

We had a very brief tour of the grounds and old city, lovely views of the river, interesting historical insights on the plaques. Beautiful old town. Recommend Nantes highly for tourists, very pleasant and interesting stop.
Great that you can enter the courtyard and walk all around the Chateau walls for free. In this day and age it's very rare to be able to do these kind of things for free.

Spend a couple hours, climb the steps or take the lift to the top of the wall to view the dancing waters and the city. The chateau was renovated several times and the time periods are noted. Well presented and revealing of the history of Nantes. I reccommend as a highlight of
and free! good place place for a walk in a chateau-setting. Nothing special, but in the heart of the city and still relaxing/peaceful
Came in here expecting an entrance fee, but unless you visit the exhibitions walking around the courtyard, enjoying the park-like grassy areas, or walking the ramparts is free!

Nantes is an amazing city and the exhibit at the Chateau des Ducs de Bretagne documents the history of the region. Many rooms have explanations in several languages. France and England have a love/hate relationship. Most interesting.
This is a small caste that is almost in the center of a town that has built up around it. It really gives a glimpse of what it must have been like to live in those l times.
Not really a 'must do' attraction, but worth a short visit and some nice views from the walls. Nice little courtyard to rest in and eat any snack you may be carrying.

We arrived in Nantes to see the Chateau and the next morning after a good nights sleep walked to the Chateau to find it closed. It was closed only on 3 days of the year Xmas dat New Year's Day and the 1st May, yes it was the 1st May, our fiery home was that night. Another try

Stayed in hotel nearby, and visited on the first Sunday of the month, when it is free and open to the public. Very interesting, be sure to wear good walking shoes. It's in very good repair. Be sure to allow at least 1-2 hours for the visit. Staff very helpful, English is
Welcoming and always worth a visit, beautiful when dusk. There is a lot to see and some good exhibitions, very good photography location

The Chateau sits centrally in Nantes, and you can walk into the courtyard and look around before buying a ticket - this may be enough for you, as the main history and building can be seen from outside. There is a free audioguide when you buy a ticket and a choice of two tapes -

Most of the outdoor spaces and ramparts are free and offer fantastic views over the castle and surrounding city. One part of the castle needs to be paid for. Section of the exhibition on slavery is interesting but overall there is not much to see and the recently refurbished

Beautiful chateau right in the heart of the city. You can walk in and around the grounds for free but must pay to enter the chateau itself. We had Nantes Pass so admission was free and included an audioguide. Really interesting artefacts and the history of the city explained as

Visited for an hour or so when in Nantes. Free to look around courtyard and walk around the battlements, which is all we did there. After wondering around, we stopped at the cafe in the courtyard. Crepes were particularly good and not too badly priced either. Just outside the
Brilliant to walk around, beautiful architecture and lovely to sit in the grounds by the moat watching the turtles on a sunny day would definatley recommend to all.

This place is not only a duchess's castle but also the museum of Nantes's history. Inside the castle are the exhibits showing the development of Nantes as an important city in Brittany. If you want to learn more about the castle rather than the city, this place may disappoint

A really wonderful museum is housed within the Chateau des Ducs de Bretagne. Using modern cutting-edge displays, you can trace history in the most wonderful of settings. The displays are all laid out in eras, and you progress through centuries before you hit the end. The cafe

English speaking tour was only was a day, in mornings so we missed it. We walked around, the guided route inside was actually very long there were a lot of detailed information available but unluckily most of it in French.

Great place to be on a rainy afternoon! Walk through 32 different rooms tracking Nantes from its founding to the present day covering the social political geographical commercial and industrial history of the city including the darker history of the slave trade. The audio

Stunning building. The museum is well worth a look but be warned there are a few stairs and it's big (some teens don't like cardio) staff really good . Well worth a look . Each room has a book in English.

Great castle in the centre of Nantes just down from the Cathedral. We parked in the Cathedral underground car park - felt very secure. The castle walls are free to go round. There are a lot of stairs but the views and ambience you get are excellent. There are information

Our French friends recommended the Chateau, and we very much enjoyed the museum portion (which is actually focused on the history of Nantes). The Chateau itself is gorgeous, however the internal rooms are remodelled into the museum (not historical rooms of the period).

a great free of charge visit to ancient times - it won't take to the interior rooms, etc, but you can take a tour around the outside walls and view over part of the city. This is a very good idea to get everyone to benefit of this valuable historical monument.

This is in the centre of the City of Nantes and dominates. It is frankly a very impressive lump. The walk around the ramparts is interesting but if you a problem with stairs then that would be challenging. Free to enter
You can visit this castle and watch city from the walls but also you can just sit near the moat and spend some time with friends and good beer :)

In the heart of the city this is a large area of peace and quite. The buildings are imposing and an all round battlement walk is available giving views across the water park. Carefully restored this is an eye opener to the opulence pre revolution.

There are no recreated rooms in this castle but you can walk all around the walls and see great views of the city. This was the one time residence of the Dukes of Brittany. From the gates youncan start your walking tour of the city. Get a map and follow the green line.
Could walk around the walls, courtyard and moat for free. Pleasant couple of hours spent. Can't comment on the paid for museum as we didn't pay.

Obviously a must see for the castle architecture. Now we have been a little bit disappointed by the visit of the museum. All modern. You then loose what was the castle interior before the museum was built. May be nothing remained. The quality of artwork displayed is on the

It is a great walk highly recommended to families and not only. Just in the heart of the city within easy walking distance from everything (the most central commerce tram station is closed but still it is easily walkable). We decided not to do the inside part of visiting the

Beautiful and imposing architecture and a lot of it to see. We paid to go inside first. Children under 18 go free which is nice incentive, unfortunately they only had guides in French left. You follow the exhibition through about 28 rooms of the castle to learn about the history
We visited only the grounds of the city castle. Touching was the memorial ship made by refugees. This was part of a special exhibition and I'm not sure for how long it will be there.

This is an interesting landmark which offers nice Renaissance architecture, located in the very centre of Nantes, so it´s quite accesible being the entrance free, unless you visit the museum. I might not be as romantic as some other castles in the region, but it really deserves

The beauty of this castle lies in it's history more than anything else. Looking into the history of 'Bretagne' prior to visiting will set you up nicely for this visit. Walking around the grounds and having a feel for the place is enough for anyone in that context. You can

The gardens in and around the castle are free to walk around and the side of the moat is good for a picnic. Walk around the inner wall for a good view of the area. Went in briefly to the museum which was interesting. The information was mainly in French. For the best view of

We really loved the Chateau des Ducs de Bretagne. We started our day with a guided tour in English (scare enough at most French tourist attractions but not here) and it really set the context for the rest of the day. Once you understand the history of a place, you can really

Very interesting but you require more than couple of hours to do it all. Very well renovated. Quite a lot to learn on the history of the area. However nothing is explained in English. Shame. Tres sympa mais necessite plus de 2 heures pour la visite. Malheureusement aucune

Great sight and view of the walls and courtyard. The large moat is dry, accessible and perfect for pic-nic on the grass. Access to walls, courtyard and moat is free of charge. Inside is paid, but I haven't been.

This is right in the heart of Nantes, high up and surrounded by a moat. Inside are two museums, one that had temporary display of icons and the other about the castle and the history of Nantes. Both are recommended.
Great castle and impressive museum. Lots of interactive displays and comprehensive history of the castle and Nantes.
A well preserved french castle, well worth a visit. Combined with a trip to the shops, a lunch or a visit to the Machines de l'isle it makes a good day out.

I went there one afternoon just to check it out because I had time to kill. The grounds are just gorgeous and you dont even have to enter the Chateau to take advantage of the grounds. This is very economical and very nice. Whether you just walk around the grounds or take the
Impressive building, with nice café bar inside the grounds. Set in the very centre of the town, its well worth a visit.Good gift shop with lots of books about the local history. Lovely rampart walks.

I did not enter as I didn't have enough time but there is much to see from the outside The tourist office is directly opposite so you can gen up before you enter It's worth a visit just to enjoy the grounds and the moat

This is one of the best castles I've been to. Absolutely stunning piece of architecture. You can walk around the outside walls, walk around the moat below, walk inside and also have your picnic in the grounds. Beautiful place - go see.

The chateau is in good repair and well worth a visit. One can walk through the grounds, sit by the moat (which was once part of the Loire) and walk all around the battements for free. There is a museum which is of some interest, but takes a lot of time and an exhibition hall. If

Walking round the ramparts and gardens are free. So it is worth a visit even if you are short of time. If you go into the chateau you can either have headphones or a guided tour. Very absorbing and interesting and worth it, but do be prepared to spend some time.
We did not pay to go inside but the grounds were lovely to walk around.Climbing the steps to the eastern wall, you can see the town and peer through the archers windows.

This is a fabulous medieval building in immaculate condition. Walking around it's outer walls overlooking the moat it can be hard to believe you are right in the heart of the fabulous city of Nantes; so peaceful and relaxing.
Gorgeous for a relaxed sunny afternoon visit. Beautifully kept and great veues for free from the top.

Great château and former home of the Dukes of Brittany. If you visit this chateau make sure that you walk around the ramparts. You can tour this monument in 1 - 1.5 hours and it is very close to the train station.
Fascinating insight in to the history of Nantes, beautiful grounds to walk around and the castle walls are great to see out in to part of the city,well worth the visit!
This place is huge. A lot of history to it. You can pay to go inside some room but a huge portion of it is free and theres lots to see and great views of the city from the battlements.
This imposing castle is close to the train station and tram lines. It is a classic castle, with a great museum inside. If you are in Nantes, make sure you vist.
2 things rolled into one, a visit to the building itself alongside a very interesting walk through the history of the city. Shows the important role Nantes played in the slave trade.
Lovely Chateau and free to walk around the grounds, you do have to pay to enter the main building, close to the main shopping area and well worth a visit.
Pretty much cool 16th century castle. Well preserved and very clean. Free entrance and walk in the courtyard and the walls. Didn't try to get in to the payed trip inside.
History and architecture all in one. Unfortunately we were too late to visit the museum but we did wall around the walls.

It's in the city centre and it's free. Outside there's the moat with a garden for a picnic and some water with birds and ducks. The walls are huge and very well preserved. You can tour around the walls and admire the landscape of the city.
If you want to have a taste of history then this place is for you. Very nice castle with great view from the wall and an interesting museum. It's beautiful from outside and inside.
Well worth an hour or so even on Mondays when most of it is closed, walk the walls take in the view - it's free.
Nice castle to look at for an hour or so. Nothing spectacularly memorable. Lots of stairs around the outside walls, from which there are some good views.

We watched the building from the outside. It shows a lot of prestige...the owners were very important people. A nice moment was when we had a coffee on a terras in front of the building. At that very moment, the sun came finally out !
We had 2 visits to this beautiful chateau in Jan, and were very appreciate that it was open during the winter months, when som many are closed.
One can't help seeing the chateau. It's big, beautiful and surrounded by a giant moat. Once inside, the grounds are clean and well-cared for. It's impressive.

This castle is right in the middle of the city and tranforms you, taking you back to the middle ages. It has a real moat and and a great restaurant. you can enter at no cost and walk the grounds but the museum is also worth it!

This is a great attraction that gives a very clear insight into the foundation of this city. As an English speaking person it was unfortunate that the video screenings are not subtitled or shown on a time basis, but don't let that deter you. Take the time to look at the books

Restored just a few years back this castle from the 15th century has a real moat, drawbridge and thick stone walls. Inside is a huge keep with several large buildings. Check out the multi-pulley well. Free admission. Recommended.
Wallow in medieval memories an amazing place of moats drawbridges Knights, Kings and princesses. Walk the ramparts and let your imagination fly

A beautiful castle in the heart of Nantes. There is a wide range of exhibitions within the castle, with a reasonable price to enter the grounds. There was a lack of information for some rooms. However, can not complain with the vast amount of artifacts and great value for

I'm not a history buff, but I was hugely impressed with this beautiful castle. A walk around the ramparts gave superb views. It was bright and welcoming (unlike many I've been to). Ideal for families. Restaurant and gift shop. Close to Tourist Office.
The castle was full of interesting history and architecture. The museum is well laid out and has interesting displays and artefacts. We ate in the café in the courtyard which was very good.

The Chateau des Ducs de Bretagne, was free entry for our visit, it is a well maintained & impressive collection of buildings, paintings and a large amount of significant historical items that are well preserved & presented. Glad we were able to visit. The relaxed Sunday
Easy to find and well-preserved site. Some for free, some for a fee. Other historic sites can be seen from ramparts. Great morning stop before going to see the machines de l'ile.
Nice to look at, but the inside is quite boring, you walk around, learn a bit about the history and that s that... But interesting to visit if you are in nantes and have an hour to spare

The Loire Valley is famous for its châteaux and vineyards. The Chateau des Ducs de Bretagne is the last one on the Loire before it dumps into the Atlantic. The remnants of the moat is interesting and the beauty of the château once inside it's walls is surprising. The views from
We only walked around the Castle without visiting the exbitions. It was an impressive sight, and a nice stroll on a sunny day. Another must-see in Nantes, close to the city centre and the cathedral.

This is a lovely place to spend an hour.The views of the city from the ramparts are very nice.THere was an exhibition on the slavery trade in one of the buildings but we did not visit it .The castle is centrally located and well worth a visit.
Excellent displays explaining the city's history. Well laid out and would suggest making this your first point of call if in Nantes for the first time
A fortified castle right in the centre of Nantes which hosted the Dukes of Brittany! You can walk round the ramparts and enjoy a drink in the courtyard!

Easily reached by car with a large underground car park a few minutes walk away. The Chateau is a very interesting place to spend a few hours. Lots to see and plenty of photo opportunities. There is also a museum detailing the history of the region which has signage in several

The Museum is perhaps a little lacking in actual exhibits - lots and lots of maps of Old Nantes, Very Old Nantes, Not Quite So Old Nantes etc, and models, but not a great deal of artefacts. Some gruesome collars and so on put on slaves who misbehaved. It is over many floors,
An excellent museum, well done for all age. I learn a lot about the history of 'Bretagne'. Unfortunately we ran out if time, so allow plenty.
a moat always adds a romantic quality for me, and this one is terrific. great old buildings and square. an interesting place to visit.

The history of slavery in Nantes... was a surprise to me. I have much to learn about the world and this was, indeed, one of those places I learned. There were several school groups at the Chateau from elementary to high school, and I stayed back to overhear some of the
Pretty castle that must offer good views of Nantes but the only one of the entire Loire valley that does not accept dogs outdoors.

Really worth a visit. Very interesting and historical with great views over the river. Great location, I would certainly go again.

We read about this castle and it was the first thing we came to visit when we arrived in Nantes. We were vacationing in Brittany in the month of March, so there was really no one to buy tickets from or anything. It was as if it was open to the public; so we went exploring.
We had bought a city card but couldn't access the museum on Easter Monday. Walk on walls was good. We used the audio guide to the city which was light on contact but gave basic information.

The museum is well organized and very interesting, with lots of well placed multimedia interpretation throughout. Even touring with active young kids we were able to learn a lot. I appreciated that the museum doesn't shy away from the hard parts of the city's history: slavery,
Very well maintained chateaux and you can walk around the outdoor areas without a ticket. Interesting exhibition on too.
Nice place to visit or spend your time. Full of history of the town. There is lots of room to visit and enyoing the past and history stories, we discower unknown Nantes there. Absolutly must visit.
We came here and the gardens and courtyard are very impressive and just beautiful! Lots of shops nearby and nice open space!

For only €5 this was a wonderful experience. The exhibit on slavery is very interesting and moving. Even though several rooms in the museum were closed, I found what was open to be excellent and really informative, without being tedious or overwhelming. Also had excellent lunch

This chateau is absolutely beautiful and extremely interesting if you like architecture. It has stunning views over the city and you can watch the crowds down below and kids skimming on the water attraction. It has a lovely atmosphere and the city of Nantes is a shoppers

Entry to the castle grounds and battlements walk is free. Museums and interior are charged for. The views of the city from the walls are great and there is a maze in the inner moat.

It's our local castle, we live in Nantes. Very interesting exhibition of Nantes history. They need to make more effort for people from other countries.
Lovely castle that is free to walk around. You pay to go into the museum etc. The grounds are very well kept and it is interesting to see the moat that surrounds it. A must do in Nantes.
The castle is in excellent shape, clean and is not expensive for visiting. It is situated in a very central place in Nantes, so you can walk to reach it, avoiding parking problems.

If you are interested in historic buildings then this is worth a couple of hours of your time. There is a museum contained within but as my time was limited I didn't go in. I was happy enough to absorb the feeling of the structure and to wander around the ramparts, the cost of
Nice for the view and the walking in the ramparts. I did not really got into the museum. Free entry!
We were surprised at the condition in a good way of the cheateau, the artworks and the good condition worth at visit.
Enteraining for children as well as adults, you get a great overview of the city. Good point is that it's free ! You can also enjoy to drink a coffee inside.
Nice Chateau right in historical center and next to Office de Tourism, for kids there is a labyrinth

Plenty of good views over the city from this magnificent building. And most of it is FREE! Lovely cafe for coffee and cake.

Loved to learn about the history of this place, queen Anne of Bretagne and France. Loved the surrounding, the moat, and that they have fruit bearing trees in the courtyard. U fortunately was not able to see the chateau inside, had no time left. Well worth visiting

This is considered the center piece of Nantes, but it really is quite bland. There are, however, many nice shops surrounding the chateau, so it is a good neighborhood to visit. The visitors bureau is directly across the street from this landmark and is worth a stop.

Highly recommend visiting the Chateau that remains standing (renovated) from the Ancient City Wall. You can stroll around the outer walls and gardens or climb up the wall for spectacular views over the city. The museum is open for visitors and cheap for what you learn. There are

We came to the Chateau as we wandered around Nantes. We didn't go inside just walked around the walls which give great views and is free.

Entrance to the chateau area is free but we took the audio tour which from memory was about 8 euros. It was well worth the cost and gave us an interesting 2 hour tour with the opportunity to learn more about the history of the place.

Great castle and the knowledge of the staff is 100% have to say they done great work fix it the last 20 years and the night lights outside castle is great to watch

After having visited so many wondrous chateaux and castles during our 5 week visit to France (especially the Loire Valley), my partner and I found this chateau to be somewhat of a letdown. There just wasn't that much to see. However, it is still worth a visit, just to see how

easy to access by the tramway city network, the first image is of a huge and impressive castle. it hosts a Museum of city history, and some othes spaces for exhibition. the museum is a bit too long, but agreable anyway
Very popular, city centre location at tram stops and near to shops. Lots of historic interest. A good visitor centre, children will enjoy
The location is beautiful, walking the ramparts is a nice experience with beautiful views of the city, tha gardens in the moat are well done and well maintained,
I was very please to cross the pond and that there is no entry fee while visiting this so beautiful place. There are some people present on the site to guide you and there is a nice souvenir shop.

A must see in Nantes! A gorgeous chateau in the middle of the city. Easy to access, near the train station. There is plenty of space inside the chateau with picnic tables so if you are looking for a nice place to eat a packed lunch this is it! It is also free to visit the first

Been several times, love walking around the castle on the outer walls, like a little step back in time. It's been build in several periods and everything is well explained (also in English). One ca visit the inside of the castle which I have still to do. A section of it is

Amazing french castle that is located in the beautiful city of Nantes. Less than 1 km from Train station, this Chateau is centre of attraction for tourist. There is a well maintained 4 floored museum in the castle which holds the antiques from 11th to 20th century. Ticket to

Walk around a medieval castle and take in the sites from atop the castle wall. This was a good way to spend a relaxing afternoon. This is a real castle complete with a moat. Guided tours of inside rooms and cellars re available for an additional costs. Worth a couple of

Thres's an exhibition about history of Nantes. I only had an image of religous place such as the Edict of Nantes. I found Nantes has developed as a harbor city. This castle is close to the station and the cathedral is near here. You don't have to take trams and enjoy walking

I didn’t pay for the entrance fee but I visited the inside patios and I walked along the ramparts. If you don’t have more than 45 minutes for visiting this monument, I advise you to do a similar visit. You’ll enjoy nice views over the city and reading the various panels you’ll

The Chateau des Ducs de Bretqgne is a marvellous set of buildings that are open to the public. You can go into the grounds and walk around the ramparts, sit on the lawns and wath the ducks for free. From time to time there are temporary exhibitions, such as the Flemish and

We could have spent more than half a day inside this amazing space. Audio guides were available (ours were free as we took advantage of a 1 day City Pass) and the commentary was excellent. Lockers were provided only for tourists it seemed, to place their bulky baggage in and
If planning on visiting Nantes. This is a must place to visit. just make my day looking at it. And the area surrounding it looks incredible too.

Lovely old Chateau that is well worth a visit. Lovely walk around the walls which is suitable for kids and free, with great views. There is a small charge to visit the museum and exhibitions which is ok if you have time! It's also worth walking around the moat - we had a fun

Pretty impressive medieval Ducal chateau..... as far as Ducal chateaux go. I feel bad in saying this but I expected more. Nantes is an amazingly innovative place, they just can’t do ordinary things. Maybe they haven’t got around to the Chateau yet.

Its lovely.If there is one thing the French do particularly well then building wonderful castles might be a contender. And its free to enter. Its in the centre of town, you can buy hot and cold drinks and children can get to see the exhibits/museum for free.
This is a must see in Nantes. Located not far from the historic old centre, this château has been restored and is an enjoyable walk with fine views of the city from the ramparts.

It is the most attractive old part of the town and well worth a visit. We restricts ourselves to the public areas. Very leased we didn't miss it. Wattt

Loved this, especially as it was free to walk around. Inside the walls, we found picnic tables etc but they were very busy. We picnicked outside the walls, looking at the chateau and its moat. Very easy to get there with public transport. We used trams.

I really enjoyed how the museum was merged with the castle structure. The multilingual books were especially clever. The interactive displays were enticing children, which is especially good to see. The interactive videos, also multilingual, were excellent (if a little slow). I

Imposing architecture, nice view from the ramparts. The place boast a very interesting, well designed historical museum (you'll have to keep climbing steep stairs up and down, though) as well as an art gallery. Plan half a day for an in-depth visit.
The title says it all, I would have preferred a bit more information on the castle's history as we went round though. Watching the duck sunbathe alongside the turtles is worth a watch.
Really enjoyed walking around the ramparts here which you can do fro free. We didn't go into the museum - maybe next time!

Well worth spending half a day here! The chateau itself is interesting for a wander around but the museum, which details both the history of the castle and of Nantes itself, needs a couple of hours at least as it has 30-odd rooms providing information on ship-building, the
Free entry and an interesting place to visit. In fact we went there three times to eat lunch, walk round the ramparts and sit by the moat. The art installation is very popular with children

This is a must see attraction if you visit Nantes. We had a most interesting tour of the Chateau, helped by the availability of an audio guide. There is so much history around Nantes and the surrounding area as you will see when you walk through time looking at the exhibits.
This is a must see if you like chateaux. It is different to a lot of the others but has a great walk on the ramparts. True the river has moved so there is not a moat but it is not far from the gare.

We didn't do the paid tour, but it's a very nice place to spend an afternoon. Free walk around the ramparts, a children's maze on the grass, and you can go inside and look at the buildings from the interior.

This is a really interesting place. The walk round the ramparts is free, beautiful and interesting. The museum takes you through the history of Nantes and deserves you spending a good chunk of time to fully appreciate it. I would have liked to see more on WW2 however.
Nice place to walk around or even sit and enjoy the weather. Had some activities for children (not our case but noticed). We didn't visit the museum but did enjoy the view from the ramparts.
